tweet: 4/5 Generally, vaccine series are completed with the same vaccine, but in some cases they can be completed with a different one. We expect results of a study measuring antibody responses to different vaccine combinations in the coming weeks.

tweet: 3/5 Currently, we know the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine has been shown to be more effective with a dose interval of 12 weeks; so those who‚Äôve received the 1st dose are recommended to wait for at least 12 weeks before receiving a 2nd vaccine dose.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/5 Canada‚Äôs FluWatch tracks the flu across year-round. There is no evidence of community circulation of flu this season. Of over 500,000 tests, only 47 flu A infections have been detected üá®üá¶-wide, including these two flus A(H1N1v and H1N2v).   https://t.co/GtVO6Lekju

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/5 H1N1v and H1N2v are variants of influenza A. They are not linked to COVID-19 and they are not a foodborne illness. We are in touch with @MBGov health officials & we will continue to keep you informed on this issue. More information:   https://t.co/mo3Y3PvDC3

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/5 Provincial & federal public health & agriculture experts are working together to investigate. The current assessment based on available evidence is that there is no increased risk to people, & no evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission at this time.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/5 These viruses usually occur after exposure to infected pigs. In Canada, there has only ever been two confirmed cases of H1N1v, and only two confirmed cases of H1N2v.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/5 Manitoba is reporting 2 separate cases of variant influenza viruses. One is a case of human influenza A (H1N2)v & one is a case of human influenza A (H1N1)v. These are rare types of flu in humans and not known to spread easily from person-to-person.  https://t.co/E01zLIrAz0

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 With the new test-based metric, the proportion of tests positive is expected to decrease compared to the previous person-based metric, as all tests will be included in the calculation, including new tests on the same person over time.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 These data replace previous #COVID19 lab metrics based on unique people tested. At this point in the pandemic, test-based metrics give a more accurate measure of overall test positivity & promote better national standardization.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 üö®NEWüö®C Starting today, reporting of #COVID19 laboratory test indicators will be based on the number of laboratory TESTS performed and the percentage of TESTS positive, which improves comparability for national reporting.  https://t.co/P2Dna7p7X5

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 Everyone is needed on the frontlines, from essential workers to volunteers to businesses, workplaces, and everyday citizens. Let‚Äôs all do our part. #StrongerTogether

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 We‚Äôve learned a lot during these many months living with #COVID19. Our challenge now and going forward is to remain united in our efforts. Public health cannot do this alone.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/3 We all have different circumstances, but when it comes to being in close contact with others, remember that every person you encounter brings their whole network & contact history with them. Every one of our actions, in every moment, matters

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/3 To help get #COVID19 infection rates ‚Üì, reduce your number of in-person close contacts and adhere to proven effective public health practices, like #physical distancing, #handwashing and staying home if you have symptoms, even mild ones.  https://t.co/w27G7rHASE

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/3 In some settings, such as group-living accommodations & public transportation where distancing can be more difficult, there are a range considerations and community-based measures available to reduce the risk of spreading #COVID19.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/4 The virus is primarily transmitted by infected people when they sneeze, cough, talk, shout or sing. When everyone wears a mask we all protect each other. For information on how to wear a non-medical mask or face covering correctly:  https://t.co/PrdV47B1Ih

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 Wearing a non-medical mask or face covering is recommended in crowded places, closed spaces with poor ventilation and close-contact situations where you cannot maintain at least two metres between yourself and others. #MaskOn

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 Maintaining #physicaldistancing is a key measure to reduce the risk of spreading the virus. I recognize this is not easy for everyone as we each face different circumstances. But, there are things you can do to lower the risk.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 #COVID19 key concerns in üá®üá¶: The number of individuals who test positive continues to ‚Üë nationally. Although there are still areas of the country where disease activity remains low, none of us, anywhere, can afford to be complacent.  https://t.co/2huCNfo7WJ

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 There are many ways you can help the #publichealth effort. Get your #flushot, sign-up to be a #FluWatcher to help monitor the spread of both #flu and #COVID19 in Canada.   https://t.co/ZxyGqcpXXy

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 You can get a #flushot at a flu clinic near you, a pharmacy that offers the flu shot, or by contacting your local #publichealth unit to find other available options in your area.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 Plan to get your #flushot as soon as it becomes available in your area. It can take up to two weeks for your body to build immunity against #flu once you get the flu shot.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 By keeping you and others healthier, the #flushot is also an important prevention measure to help reduce the burden on Canada‚Äôs health care system during #COVID19.  #SlowtheSpread

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 Getting the #flushot protects you and those around you, providing you protection from infection and serious illness, and reducing the likelihood of you spreading the illness to others. #FluSeason

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/4 Practising #physicaldistancing, #handwashing, wearing a non-medical mask or face covering and following public health guidelines are also important for helping to prevent infection and spread of both #flu and #COVID19.  https://t.co/w27G7rHASE

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 Although the #flushot doesn‚Äôt protect against infection with the virus that causes #COVID19, it helps reduce your risk of getting the flu. Having both illnesses close together in time, or at the same time, could put you at higher risk for severe illness.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 The #flushot provides protection against infection with influenza A and B viruses that are expected to circulate in the Canadian population this fall and winter while #COVID19 activity continues.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 #COVID19 key concerns in üá®üá¶: Fall is upon us, and so is the start of influenza (flu) season. The #flu, is a serious and highly contagious respiratory infection. This year it is more important than ever to get your #flushot. #FluSeason  https://t.co/02FEZyWuuV

tweet: 2/2 Staying #TogetherApart will continue to be key to our work together for the ongoing management of #COVID19. It is a fine balance, but our actions serve to limit severe outcomes, while minimising disruption to society.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/5 Keeping our close contacts low is key. This involves hard choices and puts limits on many of the things we like to do, but the more we can do our part to reduce spread of the virus, the better we can manage #COVID19 resurgences.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/5 While #testandtrace, together with isolation and quarantine remain foundational activities, local #PublicHealth cannot get ahead of #COVID19 spread where cases have large numbers of contacts they may have exposed.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/5 In recent weeks, some communities that did very well at preventing outbreaks in the spring are now facing new clusters of #COVID19. The actions of individuals are critical to slow the spread in areas with higher incidence.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/5 Ontario and Quebec continue to report the majority of daily #COVID19 cases. However, some smaller jurisdictions, including Saskatchewan, Manitoba and New Brunswick, have reported notable increases in cases as well.

tweet: 6/6 All tests currently available in Canada must be performed by a health care professional. At this time, there are no at-home test kits authorized for sale in Canada.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 Antigen tests can be helpful in regularly testing individuals in certain settings like remote work sites or crowded facilities, as well as in outbreak settings to quickly identify those who have been exposed to ensure rapid #publichealth action.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 Rapid antigen testing can be done at a point-of-care, without a lab. It requires a nasal or throat swab & can provide results in ~ 15 mins. Not as sensitive as PCR lab tests, but are accurate in early stages of infection when symptomatic & viral load ‚Üë.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 Currently approved testing methods include those which diagnose an active infection, such as PCR tests, which take nasal or throat swab samples and evaluate them in a lab. This method is quite sensitive and provides results in ~1-3 days.  https://t.co/a7SCKYCPBN

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/5 Another important reason to keep the #COVID19 infection rate low in the community is to prevent spread in these/other public settings that could necessitate targeted restrictions to control transmission where the virus is surging.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/5 Likewise, there have been #COVID19 cases and clusters in educational settings in recent weeks as schools and universities reopen. Spread in these settings is a reflection of transmission in the community and cases are not unexpected.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/5 While #COVID19 outbreaks in Long-Term Care homes are currently limited in terms of number of cases, this is an area of concern where we must continue to strengthen measures to prevent introductions and control spread.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/5 Although #COVID19 outbreaks continue to be reported in Long-Term Care homes, most of these involve a small number of cases due to heightened vigilance and control measures in these settings.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/4 Keeping to your close-contacts bubble is safest, but when going to public spaces it is important to assess your personal risks and check that there are controls in place to reduce spread of the virus and continue to follow good public health practices.  https://t.co/w27G7rHASE

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 In fact, it is in these familiar settings where we may be most apt to let our guard down, increasing our risk of infection and unintentionally spreading the virus to others in our homes, workplaces and communities.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 This is a reminder that just because you may know the people attending an event outside of your household/close-contacts bubble, it doesn‚Äôt mean there is a reduced risk of #COVID19.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 With increased #COVID19 case counts, outbreaks are being reported in various settings, including private social gatherings/celebrations, community/indoor settings, with many exposures and infections linked to single events.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/3 It‚Äôs on all of us to keep #COVID19 epidemic growth in check! We need to keep our #ContactBubble small and keep up #publichealth practices: #PhysicalDistancing, #handwashing and #MaskOn where distancing is difficult.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/3 Just one person infected with #COVID19, even if only experiencing mild symptoms, can start a chain reaction of exposures & infections, spreading to many people in their homes, workplaces, communities and other settings.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 Increased disease activity, poses a risk for accelerated or #exponential epidemic growth. This fast-paced growth, as we experienced during Apr/May, is difficult to control with #TestandTrace and can throw us off the #SlowBurn path.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 NACI‚Äôs health professionals, scientists and researchers conduct extensive review of the research and ensure that the highest standards of safety and efficacy are met before making recommendations on the use of vaccines in  Canada.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 A key component of the vaccine process in Canada is our National Advisory Committee on Immunizations (NACI). For over >50 years NACI has safeguarded our health, reviewing the research on vaccines, and making recommendations for their use in üá®üá¶.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/5 and must meet our usual high standards for safety and efficacy in order for approval for use in Canada. As always, even after a vaccine is approved for use, there will be ongoing monitoring of safety & effectiveness in the population.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/5 Canada will work collaboratively with international partners to review the safety and efficacy of vaccine(s). Candidate vaccines for #COVID19 prevention and control must be tested extensively among many 1000s of volunteers...

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/5 To do that without compromising safety, @GovCanHealth has given #COVID19 vaccine (or vaccines) top priority at #PHAC and #HealthCanada will dedicate additional scientists to assist with the review and approval process.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/5 Thanks to decades of research in vaccine development, and advances in technology over the last 20 years, organizations in Canada and around the world are able to expedite the vaccine development process for #COVID19.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/5 The development and approval of a #COVID19 vaccine for Canadians will build on the existing strengths and experience of Canada‚Äôs vaccine research and safety review process.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 while ramping up collaboration and coordination to tighten partnerships, and prepare, plan and run as many of these vital steps in parallel as is feasible and appropriate. #VaccinesWork

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 No step will be skipped and no corner will be cut from Canada‚Äôs well-established vaccine development and quality assurance process; Fast-tracking means building on our robust domestic experience and expertise...

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 And we cannot _and will not_ compromise on safety and effectiveness. Development and approval of a #COVID19 vaccine for Canadians will build on existing strengths and experience of üá®üá¶‚Äôs vaccine research & safety review process.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 The vaccine research and development process during usual times takes more than a decade before a safe and effective vaccine is approved for use in Canada. Canada, and the world, cannot wait 10 years for a #COVID19 vaccine...

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/5 Likewise, Saskatchewan is reporting historic levels of overdoses and #overdose deaths and in Quebec, the number of overdose deaths in Montreal during July 2020 was the highest seen in over five years.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/5 For the third consecutive month this year, the number of drug #overdose deaths recorded in British Columbia has exceeded 170. These deaths represent a 136% increase over the number of deaths recorded in July 2019.

tweet: 5/5 Hospitalizations and ICU admissions for #COVID19 remain low, with < 400 individuals in hospitals and < 100 individuals in critical care across the country on any given day over the last several weeks.

tweet: 3/4 This overall approach has been popularly described as the ‚ÄúHammer and the Dance‚Äù.   https://t.co/LWxJQU8EEl

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 Following this is a longer phase of less restrictive #publichealth measures (#PhysicalDistancing, #Handwashing, #MaskOn, #TestandTrace) to keep #COVID19 under manageable control, as we cautiously reopen social & economic spaces.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 Informed by mathematical modelling, the approach to #COVID19 pandemic control involved an initial phase of strong #publichealth measures (e.g. closures) to stop #exponential growth that threatened to overwhelm the health system.

tweet: 4/4 Our efforts have also bought us time as research and #science accelerate at an unprecedented pace towards finding safe and effective treatments and vaccines against #COVID19. #GoScience #Innovation #Canada

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

tweet: 1/4 #COVID19 #science continues to evolve at a rapid pace and we must continue to be guided by the best available evidence. #BePartofTheSolution

tweet: 4/4 These adaptations have been challenging. And, the uncertainties of the #COVID19 pandemic have been stressful, taking a toll on the physical and emotional wellbeing of individuals, families and communities. #COVIDCoping

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 #PHAC has recently released new breastfeeding resources, which include guidance and ideas in support of a positive breastfeeding experience including 10 Valuable Tips for Successful Breastfeeding:  https://t.co/IH1WzYL1uQ

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 I encourage programs + practitioners to find virtual ways to offer support by phone or online; families & friends to reach out to support new parents around them; and #breastfeeding parents to seek help when they need it. #HelpOthers

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 #Breastfeeding is a skill that mothers and infants learn together and support is important. During these times of #PhysicalDistancing, there may be less in‚Äìperson breastfeeding supports/programs operating.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 This includes frequent #handwashing, practising proper respiratory etiquette (#CoverYourCough) and wearing a non-medical mask or face covering when close to the baby. This advice goes to all new parents, whether breastfeeding or not.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 Anyone who has symptoms, even if mild, or is concerned they may have been exposed to #COVID19 should take recommended precautions to avoid spreading the virus to the baby.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/6 Mothers with suspected or confirmed #COVID19 are still encouraged to initiate or continue #breastfeeding.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/5 #Breastfeeding provides custom-made nutrition and immune protection for your #baby to help keep them safe from viruses like the flu. See this new resource for more:  https://t.co/LQGpD8Narq

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/5 We are still learning about #COVID19. Currently, there is little evidence that the virus is spread from a mother to her infant through breastfeeding and the benefits of #breastfeeding are considered to far outweigh any potential risks.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/5 These past months of #COVID19 have been stressful for many Canadians, including new and expectant parents. At the outset, we knew very little about how the virus would spread and impact pregnant women & their newborns

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/5 August 1- 7th is #WorldBreastfeedingWeek. Canada highlights the importance of #breastfeeding twice a year - in August, as we celebrate with others around the globe, and in October, as we celebrate our national Breastfeeding Week.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 It is no secret that there is a lot of #misinformation out there on #COVID19. Following the wrong lead can be distracting and harmful. Every one has a role in making sure our sights and energies are focussed on the right path. #infodemic

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 Questions are healthy; they challenge us to think things over from many perspectives to reach conclusions that can stand up to healthy scrutiny. We all need to scrutinise what we read, hear and decide to share. #infodemic #GetTheFacts

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 For some people, change won‚Äôt be quick enough, for others it will be too quick, or not convincing enough. Everyone will have questions, some more than others. This is perfectly acceptable and there are no wrong questions. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 While some decisions have to be made when the evidence is incomplete, we must remain open to all lines of inquiry, carefully gather the evidence, and adapt our #COVID19 approaches as the science evolves.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 Dealing with the adaptations and uncertainties of an emerging disease event on this scale has been difficult, to say the least, but the stakes are high and we must take an approach informed by the best available #science and evidence.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 Canadians have made many sacrifices. I‚Äôm thankful to the great majority who continue to follow #publichealth practices, incl. wearing a non-medical mask/facial covering in indoor public spaces & when #PhysicalDistancing is difficult.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/5 If we stick to activities in a small, consistent social bubble; practise #PhysicalDistancing; avoid higher-risk settings; & layer on precautions (#Handwashing, wearing a mask) we can keep the pressure on & squeeze the virus out of our summer plans.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/5 Places that once had #COVID19 under control are not immune to resurgence, as seen in several countries.  üá®üá¶doesn‚Äôt have to be one of those places. We can stop #COVID19 from finding opportunities to spread and surge. #WeAreCanadian

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/5 We‚Äôve been taught some hard lessons. Summer doesn‚Äôt make the virus go away, and gatherings and absence of #COVID19 precautions present key opportunities for exposure and spreading or superspreading the virus.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/5 This summer, the virus that causes #COVID19 is active worldwide and looking for the next place to stage a big comeback, while making stops along the way wherever opportunities exist. #StoptheSpread

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/8 #TakeThatStep to access #MentalHealth supports and resources that are available to help. @CdnTogether Wellness Portal offers a wide range of resources and support for mental wellness and substance use issues for Canadians.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/8 There are many things we can do to take care of our #MentalHealth and it‚Äôs especially important to do so during the pandemic. #PHAC has published tips on how to take care of your mental and physical health during this time.  https://t.co/wIdLNbGfF7

tweet: 2/6 These emotional and psychological impacts can lead to feelings of loneliness and social isolation. There is support and help; #TakeThatStep for #COVIDCoping and remember, you can practice #PhysicalDistancing and still be social.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/6 Layers of #publichealth precautions and #PhysicalDistancing can leave us all feeling a bit of #COVIDfatigue. For many, there are emotional and psychological implications to staying physically apart from others. #COVID19 #COVIDCoping

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/4 When in CLOSED SPACES, CROWDED SPACES or in CLOSE CONTACT with people outside our social bubble, whether indoors or outdoors, we need an additional layer of protection by wearing a non-medical mask or face covering.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 While there are ways we can stay socially connected during #COVID19, including by expanding and enriching our virtual connections, we also need to remember to layer other protections when distancing is difficult to maintain.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 #PhysicalDistancing 2-metres from people outside your social bubble is one of the most effective ways to prevent spread of #COVID19, but it‚Äôs not without challenges, socially/practically, esp. at certain times, in certain settings.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 Early diagnosis and treatment of viral #hepatitis are key for better health outcomes.  Hepatitis A and B are types of viral hepatitis that are preventable by vaccination.  While there is no vaccine to prevent hepatitis C, it can be cured with effective treatment. #EndStigma

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 To keep #COVID19 ‚Üì we need all Canadians working together with #publichealth, especially young adults aged 20-39 years who account for the HIGHEST INCIDENCE RATES ACROSS ALL AGES during the past 2 weeks.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 In this all-Canadian #COVID19 #TugOfWar, the virus is attempting to pull us back, but we can‚Äôt let it win, we can‚Äôt lose our ground. #DoYourPart - Don‚Äôt be the one that let go of the rope on #TeamCanada.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/4 #PublicHealth functions are critical for keeping #COVID19 epidemic growth in check and ultimately for protecting the health system as well as the functioning of our economy and society.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 Keeping #COVID19 under control means keeping case and contact numbers as low as possible so #publichealth authorities are able to manage the workload of testing & isolating cases and tracing & quarantining contacts. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 Although we know we can‚Äôt eliminate all cases and clusters of #COVID19, we need to keep on top of things to prevent a re-acceleration of growth that could quickly get out of hand.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 The upward trend in #COVID19 daily case counts is worrisome. We know that we have the means to keep the epidemic under control, but THIS IS NOT A SURE THING. The virus doesn‚Äôt care about our past efforts. It‚Äôs what we do now that matters.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/4 Since then, the lowest average was 273 cases reported daily in early July. However most recently, we are starting to see the daily case count trend upwards again, with the latest 7-day rolling average at 487 cases reported daily.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 The 7-day average also allows us to compare the current trend with prior weeks of the #COVID19 epidemic, e.g., looking back to the peak of daily case counts in early May, üá®üá¶ was averaging close to 1,800 cases reported daily.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 Since #COVID19 individual daily case counts can fluctuate from day to day, it helps to look at the average of the daily case count over the most recent 7 days to see how quickly and in what direction (‚Üë  or ‚Üì) the epidemic is trending.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 #COVID19 key concerns in üá®üá¶: as we reopen, we need to be laser focussed on daily case counts. Monitoring the average daily case count (based on a 7-day rolling average) is an important early indicator of epidemic activity and trend.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/3 üá®üá¶ your actions matter!  Every decision we make to reduce our risk of exposure and every precaution we take to slow the spread of #COVID19 in our communities, can help prevent a reacceleration of the epidemic.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/3 We all need to be aware of the type and range of #COVID19 symptoms to look out for so we can monitor our health closely. Remember, it can take up to 14 days for symptoms to appear after exposure to the virus.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/3 Early on, it was known that a typical symptomatic case of #COVID19 may present with cough, fever and shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, but over time, it‚Äôs become clear that there are other commonly reported symptoms.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: Your actions matter ‚Äì you have a role to play in keeping your community safe from #COVID19. These simple steps will help you make informed choices to reduce the spread:  https://t.co/G8TOurHPpL  https://t.co/AkxMQpaUdw

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/7 Using ALL of these layers of protection is essential to minimizing your risk for #COVID19 and reducing spread in your community. As we continue to live with #COVID19, how will you layer up?

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/7 On top of these layers, always follow the: ‚û°Ô∏è advice of local public health as it is tailored to the area where you live:  https://t.co/0nWFHHGDCx ‚û°Ô∏è safety measures put in place by the establishment you are visiting. ‚û°Ô∏è latest information on #COVID19:  https://t.co/amTxOwDHM9

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/7 Your outer layer is about making informed decisions about your personal risk, planning ahead and avoiding the 3 Cs: üö´ Closed spaces with poor ventilation üö´ Crowded places with large numbers of people gathered üö´ Close contact where you cannot keep 2 metres apart from others

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/7 Then, add layers for extra protection:  ‚úîÔ∏è Wear a non-medical mask or face covering when it is difficult to stay 2 metre apart from others and when mandated by local authorities  ‚úîÔ∏è Carry a pocket-sized hand sanitizer with you wherever you go

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/7 #PublicHealth practices are most effective when they‚Äôre combined. Build a base layer by sticking to the basics:  ‚úîÔ∏è #PhysicalDistancing  ‚úîÔ∏è #Handwashing often ‚úîÔ∏è #StayHome if even mildly ill ‚úîÔ∏è #CoughEtiquette ‚úîÔ∏è Stick to a small, consistent social circle

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/7 ‚ÄúLayer up‚Äù this summer to reduce your risk of exposure to #COVID19. #PublicHealth practices are ‚Äúlayers of protection‚Äù. Just like hats, gloves, mitts, and a winter jacket, one item alone is not enough to protect you from the elements.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/7 Go OUT SMART. Remember to practice #PhysicalDistancing, #GoodHygiene, incl. meticulous #handwashing, #StayHomeIfSick and wear a non-medical mask or face covering when it‚Äôs difficult to keep 2m <-> distance from others.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/7 When you are outside of your home, using public transportation, or out in public spaces, carry a Health Canada-approved hand sanitizer to disinfect your hands, when soap and water are not available.  https://t.co/ExOoFli6DD

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/7 At home: door or cabinet handles, light switches, handrails, faucets, countertops, toilets, electronics, toys, phones, tablets, television remotes, & bedside tables. In the car: door handles, steering wheel, and other frequently touched surfaces.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/7 We do know that the virus is easily killed by cleaning with regular household cleaners or diluted bleach according to the label directions. It is important to clean and disinfect your personal environment.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/7 We don‚Äôt know yet exactly how long the virus causing #COVID19 lives on surfaces. Current evidence suggests it can live on objects and surfaces for anywhere from a few hours to days.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/7 #COVID19 is most often spread through close contact with an infectious person via respiratory droplets. Less often, it can be spread when someone touches something with the virus on it, then touches their mouth, nose or eyes, before washing hands.

tweet: 8/8 Friends, families, and employers and employees alike need to support each other so we can continue to track #COVID19 transmission and keep it under control.  #StoptheStigma

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/8 People who test positive for #COVID19 are helping prevent further spread by staying home in isolation & helping local #publichealth officials to trace contacts.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/8 If you have symptoms, stay home & away from others, even if you‚Äôre only mildly ill. Contact local #publichealth to determine how to proceed to get tested. People who get tested are protecting those around them.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/8 Also, people without symptoms may be infected with the virus. If you think you have been exposed to the virus, stay home and contact local #publichealth for advice on next steps, including when and how to seek testing.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/8 Be aware of #COVID19 symptoms.  The most common include: fever, cough, & shortness of breath, fatigue, loss of appetite & loss of smell or taste. Less common symptoms include, but are not limited to, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting & muscle aches.  https://t.co/snEQaUW8u3

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/8 Despite the widespread acceptance and everyday practice of #publichealth measures ‚Äì #handwashing, #physicaldistancing + wearing a mask in crowded places - it is possible that you or somebody you know will test positive for #COVID19.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/3 Some people are tested multiple times, such as healthcare workers. These individuals are counted each time they are tested. So, üá®üá¶ has tested > 3 million people for #COVID19 and this includes some individuals tested multiple times.

tweet: 2/3 These numbers reflect the number of PEOPLE tested. We count PEOPLE because SAMPLING and TESTING approaches vary by jurisdiction & over time. Also, 1 PERSON can be tested in different ways using multiple SAMPLES (i.e., nasal swab, oral swab, both).

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: Spending time in the great Canadian outdoors can lower the risk of exposure to #COVID19. Activities in the open air are safer than indoor. Thank you Mother Nature for these wonderful days of summer. #ThankYouThursday  https://t.co/ucTRHenp54

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/8 #EndTB is a priority for Canada.  We have effective treatments and rapid diagnostic tests, and we have community-driven models we know work.  As we fight #COVID19, let us not lose sight of our goal to eliminate #TB in Canada.  https://t.co/7vBp1v1UZW

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/8 Solutions will be driven by communities. Key to this is integrating First Nations and Inuit cultural perspectives and traditional knowledge into health care and public health practices, while recognizing the right to self-determination.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/8 Infection control practices, case detection and contact tracing are essential elements in the response to both #COVID19 and #TB. These must be coupled with efforts to support communities & address inequities.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/8 Like #COVID19, #TB disproportionately affects those experiencing poverty, inadequate housing & social inequities. TB rates in üá®üá¶ are low, but unacceptably high among Inuit, First Nations & newcomers, from countries where TB is more common.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/8 When a person breathes in the bacteria, they may become infected and the bacteria may lay dormant in their body (latent TB infection) or develop later in life into active TB disease.  https://t.co/kL8zG45T1m

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/8 #TB is caused by certain bacteria, which spread person-to-person through the air when a case of active TB disease coughs or sneezes. Unlike #COVID19, TB bacteria can stay airborne for several hours.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/8 As we continue to fight #COVID19, we are also moving forward in our fight against another infectious disease #tuberculosis (#TB). TB is preventable and curable, yet it remains one of the most common infectious diseases worldwide. #EndTB

tweet: 4/6 A beacon in the fight to #EndStigma, the HIV community‚Äôs provision of culturally appropriate care & support, particularly in Indigenous communities, has served as models and improved responses to other health challenges, including #COVID19.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 14/14 Canada needs all the volunteer #COVID19 firefighters we can get ‚Äì help smother the embers by keeping #publichealth practices UP and your number of contacts DOWN ‚Äì public health thanks you!! #TeamCanada

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 13/14 Limiting the number of contacts that we each have is also important as it means less fuel for any fires that do start. This will allow #PublicHealth to rapidly complete contact tracing and keep #COVID19 under control. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 12/14 That‚Äôs where Canadians come in. By keeping ‚Üë #PhysicalDistancing + #GoodHygiene and AVOIDING high risk exposure settings like closed spaces, crowded places and close contact situations, WE stop new fires from starting as we reopen.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 11/14 Ultimately, the success of case finding and contact tracing is in the speed and completeness with which it is done. The fewer the number of cases and contacts, the faster and more completely new fires can be extinguished.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 10/14 Similarly contacts, few or many, need information and support to quarantine and monitor for #COVID19 symptoms, while #PublicHealth follow up continues for weeks until cases and contacts no longer pose a risk for spread to others.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 9/14 But the work doesn‚Äôt stop there. Cases who are identified need to be provided with education and support on how to self-isolate to ensure they do not expose others to the virus.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/14 Contact tracing comes next and involves, tracking down every person who may have been exposed to the case, either directly through close contact, or indirectly in a shared space like a home or workplace.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/14 Case investigation involves local #publichealth identifying #COVID19 cases through lab testing and conducting exposure investigations to understand how/where cases were infected and who they may have spread the infection to.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/14 Thanks to Canadians‚Äô collective efforts in our biggest ‚Äúbucket brigade‚Äù to date, the big fire is out and local #publichealth #COVID19 fighters can now do what they do best ‚Äì case investigation and contact tracing to control smaller fires!

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/14 This is why closure of social and economic spaces was required, much like a countrywide fire ban, to bring the #COVID19 epidemic under control and not overwhelm the health system.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/14 When epidemic growth is increasing exponentially, as it did at the beginning of the #COVID19 epidemic in Canada, there were too many little fires that quickly merged into a big blaze, overwhelming #TestandTrace capacity.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/14 The more fires there are to put out, the greater the risk that #PublicHealth capacity and resources will be overwhelmed trying to get to all the fires before the wind shifts and starts an uncontrollable blaze.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/14 If we think of #COVID19 cases as small fires (and contacts like dry grass waiting to ignite), local #PublicHealth are the firefighters and case isolation, contact tracing/quarantine is like dousing with water to control the blaze.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/14 #PublicHealth Contact Tracing 101 & YOU: Achieving and maintaining low levels of #COVID19 activity is crucial for minimizing illness and deaths, but it also preserves capacity for #TestandTrace to bring the epidemic under control.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/3 Contact tracing is a vital tool for #COVID19 epidemic control and all Canadians have a role to play in preserving this #publichealth capacity. Read my next thread on ‚ÄúContact Tracing and You 101‚Äù. #DoYourPart

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/3 Keeping #PhysicalDistancing + #GoodHygiene ‚Üë & AVOIDING high risk -CLOSED SPACES, CROWDED PLACES & CLOSE CONTACT- helps keep our daily # of contacts low so #publichealth is able to rapidly #TestandTrace to control flare-ups.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/3 This is an #OldieButAGoodie. As we reopen, stay home means #StayHomeIfSick. #PhysicalDistancing remains as important as it ever was, but as we adapt to living with #COVID19, #DoYourPart has new meaning for epidemic control.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/4 Avoiding CROWDED places, CLOSED spaces, and CLOSE-CONTACT w\ others lowers the risk of exposure and enables #PublicHealth to rapidly detect/isolate most cases and trace/quarantine most contacts to keep #COVID19 controlled.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 To keep #COVID19 ‚Üì as üá®üá¶ reopens and restrictions relax, it is EVEN MORE IMPORTANT that Canadians continue with collective #publichealth practices + AVOID high risk settings to keep our daily number of contacts down.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 The efforts of Canadians working collectively to #StayHomeIfSick and maintain practices like keeping 2 metres of #PhysicalDistancing from others and #HandWashing often has allowed us to #CrushtheCurve of #COVID19. #TeamCanada

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/3 #COVID19 key concerns in üá®üá¶: it is now 100 days since Canada reported its 100th person with COVID-19 and we now have over 100,000 reported cases. This is a good moment to reflect on what the latest numbers mean for Canadians.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/8 That‚Äôs why, YOUR actions matter to help keep #COVID19 down to low enough levels that #publichealth is able to #TestandTrace to find & isolate new cases and quarantine contacts. #WeAreAllinThisTogether

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/8 But WITH #publichealth measures we can reduce the number of new people infected by each case to less than 1 new case (R<1), which will slow the spread, stop exponential epidemic growth and KEEP #COVID19 CONTROLLED.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/8 This is the math behind the basic reproductive number (R) that represents how contagious #COVID19 is. WITHOUT public health measures each case spreads to ~3 others (R=3), with a new generation starting about every 4 days and so on...

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/8Starting from YOU x 3 contacts, then on from YOUR 3 contacts x their 3 contacts and so forth, in just 10 generations of spread over ~5 weeks (4 days/generation), a total of 88,572 cumulative cases can accumulate, like this:

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/8 The degree of #COVID19 CONTROL vs. SPREAD depends on the #Publichealth measures we all continue to take. Without #PhysicalDistancing, #Handwashing, #CoughEtiquette, & non-medical masks where recommended, here is what can happen:

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/8 Think of yourself as the red dot in the middle who could spread to 3 contacts IF no #publichealth measures. This shows just 3 generations of spread from 1 (YOU) to 39 other cases in just 12 days (~4 days btw. each generation).  https://t.co/8sVBal7dOA

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/8 Here‚Äôs the [fairly] simple math on why YOUR actions matter. 1 case of #COVID19 spread to ~3 people X 10 generations of spread (IF NO #PUBLICHEALTH MEASURES) = 88,573 cumulative cases & many deaths in just ~5 weeks. See how it happens:

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 Studies like this strengthen the #science for evidence-based decision-making to control #COVID19. Additional & larger studies of #SARS-CoV-2 #infectivity will help us learn more about when people are most likely to spread the virus.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 This is the largest study of #SARS-CoV-2 #infectivity of its kind. Findings support current #publichealth recommendations to isolate #COVID19 cases in the community for at least 10 days after symptom onset.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 The study showed that patient samples taken from the day symptoms started to 8 days after symptom onset could still infect test cells (Vero cells) in culture but samples collected >8 days after symptom onset did not infect test cells. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 #COVID19 diagnostic tests (RT-PCR) detect viral particles (RNA) that can remain in the body for varying lengths of time following infection. The study looked at samples to see if they contained live virus capable of infecting others.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 #PHAC‚Äôs National Microbiology Laboratory (NML) partnered with researchers in Manitoba to study 90 samples taken from Manitobans with #COVID19 at different points of time from 0 to 21 days after symptom onset.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/6 Recent research in üá®üá¶ sheds light on when people with #COVID19 are most likely to spread the virus to others. Results support isolation of #COVID19 cases for at least 10 days after symptom onset to stop transmission.    https://t.co/7eJ7Fy4FTw

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 With the amount of information that we consume each day, it is more important than ever to ask these questions and seek out trusted and reliable sources of information. The #GoC website is a good place to start  https://t.co/5Z5UAZI2rm

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 We all have a responsibility to #StoptheSpread of #misinformation. As the wise 13th century Persian poet, Rumi, said: Before you speak, let your words pass through three gates: Is it true? Is it necessary? It is kind?

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 9/9 The trust your contacts have in you can make disinformation seem more authentic & believable. Instead:  - Share credible information/sites like  https://t.co/5Z5UAZI2rm - Report & warn others if you see #disinformation.  - Learn more from sites like  https://t.co/TTJE97GWat

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/9 When you see something and share it with friends, neighbours, colleagues or acquaintances, you are giving it a stamp of approval and increasing the credibility of the information. #checkthenshare

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/9 It may be difficult to stop all disinformation from reaching us given the systematic and highly convincing ways it reaches our screens and devices but WE CAN PLAY A PART IN STOPPING IT from spreading to others.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/9 People or groups running organised campaigns may share false information using sophisticated marketing for political, money generating or other less-than-admirable reasons. #disinformation #infodemic

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/9 Deliberate creation of false or misleading information is called disinformation. Sources of disinformation can range from ‚Äúrobots‚Äù or ‚Äúbots‚Äù that are set up to blast out mass communications to people with an agenda. #misinformation

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/9 Although well-intentioned people may share misinformation that they BELIEVE to be true, the source can often be traced back to a deliberate fabrication. #COVID19 #misinformation  #infodemic

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/9 We need to learn to spot & stop misinformation, which detracts from progress & causes real harm. During #COVID19, it is like dealing with two epidemics spreading, the disease & misinformation about the disease. #infodemic #StoptheSpread

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/9 My statement discusses the issue of misinformation, which is the unintentional sharing of false or misleading information. There is no place for misinformation on any day, least so during a crisis on the scale of #COVID19.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 9/9 Help keep our surveillance and testing sensitive. #HelpOthers by supporting friends, neighbours & colleagues who go for testing, especially those who test positive for #COVID19, no one is immune to infection. #AllinThisTogether #KindnessMatters

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/9 Canadians can play an important role in testing, By ensuring everybody has stigma-free and barrier free laboratory testing, we can ensure optimal access to testing, allowing us to detect cases early & stop #COVID19 transmission quickly.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/9 These numbers/%s are important for #publichealth & governments at all levels to maintain careful monitoring of  #COVID19 surveillance sensitivity and to make adjustments to laboratory testing & epidemic control strategies as needed.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/9 This past week, an average of 33,000 people were tested daily across üá®üá¶ , with 2% of these people testing positive. This low % positive indicates that our surveillance is sensitive, testing broadly to pick up #COVID19 cases. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/9 üá®üá¶ has maintained <10% positive #COVID19 lab tests throughout the pandemic. As #Publichealth #TestandTrace has intensified, the daily number of people tested has steadily increased and the % positive has continued to decline.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/9 In #COVID19 hotpots, testing many people with even mild symptoms, and in some cases testing people at risk who may NOT be showing symptoms, ensures that we are looking hard to #TestandTrace to find & stamp out chains of transmission.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/9 We aim for a low percentage positive, below 10%, which is an international benchmark. This indicates we are casting our net wide enough to capture any cases that may be occurring in the area.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/9  A high % positive, indicates that we may not be testing enough to detect all the cases. We want to cast our net wide around where the virus is spreading.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/9 So how do we know we are testing enough? One way is to monitor the % of positive tests among all of the #COVID19 tests conducted over the course of a week.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: There are three ways we test for #COVID19 in Canada:   ‚û°Ô∏èMolecular PCR  ‚û°Ô∏èPoint of Care  ‚û°Ô∏èSerology testing   Watch this video to find out how each test is administered and how quickly you can expect to receive results:   https://t.co/77rJo6hHDf

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/4 Testing the right person, at the right time, in the right place is important for effective #TestandTrace. Provincial & territorial chief medical officers of health provide guidance on who should be tested, based on #COVID19 activity.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 Labs across üá®üá¶ have been building up testing capacity w\ equipment, supplies, resources. Capacity is now in place to test > 60,000 people daily & work continues to prepare for any possible surge in #COVID19 activity into the fall. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 Testing & isolating cases, as well as tracing & quarantining contacts, as quickly as possible, is a key part of our #COVID19 control strategy to stop new chains of transmission from re-igniting the epidemic going forward. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 #COVID19 key concerns in üá®üá¶: as we lift some control measures to reopen social & economic activities, we need to double down on #publichealth #TestandTrace, while maintaining #PhysicalDistancing & #Goodhygiene for epidemic control.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 Severe outcomes of #COVID19 are rare among children & youth. The most commonly reported symptoms were cough, runny nose & headache; only 2% needed hospital care and NO deaths have been reported in the <20 age group in Canada.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 Canadian data to date show that children & youth are more likely to experience mild illness or show no symptoms at all from #COVID19; 11% of lab-confirmed cases in children & youth were asymptomatic compared to 2-4% of adult cases.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/6 Although the majority of #COVID19 cases reported in Canada are adults, no age group is immune and cases have been reported in all age groups, including among children and youth.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 This gives me gives me the hope and belief that, despite the uncertainty ahead, Canadians will keep working together and supporting each other to protect our families, our communities, and our society from #COVID19. #WeWillGetThroughThis #cavabienaller

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 It‚Äôs been difficult dealing with these weeks and months of #COVID19 uncertainty, but Canadians have united with determination to get us through adversity #StrongerTogether. #MondayMotivation

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 Taken together, outbreaks & hotspots remind that us we‚Äôve got to continue our path down the #COVID19 curve with caution, maintaining #PhysicalDistancing & #GoodHygiene practices everywhere to avoid new flare ups.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 Provinces have been mobilising more testing to trace and control any lingering chains of transmission in these most affected areas. #COVID19 #TestandTrace

tweet: 4/4 Living with #COVID19 means the possibility of rebound remains EVERYWHERE if public health measures are relaxed too much. Recall, models show THE FATE OF THE POSSIBILITIES IS UP TO US. #PhysicalDistancing #Handwashing #CoughEtiquette

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 Until we can keep Rt consistently below 1, where each new case spreads to LESS THAN one other person for  several weeks steady, #COVID19 will continue to smoulder. We need to #KeepItUp as #Publichealth stamp out with #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 Rt estimates the # of new infections spread from a single case. Currently  üá®üá¶‚Äôs Rt is hovering around 1 (cautiously good news), but this is not the same everywhere; in some areas Rt is well below 1, in others it is closer to 1 & fluctuating.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 At present, #COVID19 transmission is continuing in outbreak settings & some communities, esp. in & around our most populous cities, Toronto & Montreal. Hotspots contribute to fluctuations in üá®üá¶ ‚Äôs nat‚Äôl effective reproduction rate (or Rt).

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/7 As well, #COVID19 has exploited social and economic vulnerabilities & inequalities across Canadian society, taking hold in settings and among communities who experience overcrowding, lower incomes & health disparities. #HealthInequity  https://t.co/kzf8r6kMMS

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/7 But seniors in long-term care & assisted living have been most severely impacted. > 900 separate outbreaks in these settings account for ~20% of all #COVID19 cases but a heartbreaking 85% of all deaths in üá®üá¶. #ProtecttheVulnerable

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/7 Over the course #COVID19 in üá®üá¶, outbreaks have been reported in acute care settings, daycares, correctional facilities and workplaces, including Canada‚Äôs largest outbreak linked to a meat packing plant.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/7 The composite picture of #COVID19 in üá®üá¶ has been characterised by a series of regional, now localised outbreaks & hotspots of ongoing community transmission. Epidemic growth fluctuations in areas of Ontario are a key concern.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/7 Quebec & Ontario have dominated #COVID19 cases, accounting for over 86% reported cases overall & over 90% in last 2 weeks.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/7 However, the pattern, extent & drivers of #COVID19 have varied greatly across üá®üá¶, ranging from zero cases in Nunavut & no community spread in PEI/other territories to community spread with varying degrees of control in other provinces.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

tweet: 6/6 It is also important to keep up to date with routine #vaccination and to maintain regular health visits. Please speak to your #healthcare provider to learn about the options available, including virtual appointments.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 While children & youth are resilient, we need to support their physical & mental wellness, e.g. by talking openly with them, answering their questions, calming their fears and engaging them in healthy activities.  https://t.co/caXIktIZtS

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 ...whether because of illness in the family, closure of school & recreation programs, or missing social connections while #PhysicalDistancing. Also, #COVID19 is exacerbating existing inequalities, making life more challenging for many Canadians.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 But, we cannot ignore the direct and indirect impacts that #COVID19 has had on young people. While the number of cases among children and youth has remained low, young people have experienced major disruptions in their lives‚Ä¶

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 In particular, seniors living in long-term care homes have borne the disproportionate impacts & severe outcomes of #COVID19. Prevention & control of COVID-19 in this population is crucial for minimizing morbidity & mortality. #ProtecttheVulnerable

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/6 Although people of any age can develop #COVID19, some people are at higher risk for hospitalization and death including #OlderAdults and people with chronic medical or immune compromising health conditions.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 The epidemiologic data tell us we are on the right track with the epidemic currently coming under control in most parts of Canada. Modelling tells us we need to #KeepitUp to maintain epidemic control of #COVID19 going forward.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 Table 1 above, from the CCDR article, shows these outcomes as rate estimates per million population as opposed to the total numbers that appear in the #GOC April 28th update on modelling.   https://t.co/QJTl2ILv0R

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 Table 1 translates this as the range of POSSIBLE outcomes for Canada over the course of the #COVID19 pandemic. Applying public health measures with  intensity achieves greater epidemic control.  https://t.co/O1d5Q2R2v3

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6‚¨ÜÔ∏è intensity of #publichealth measures work to keep #COVID19‚¨áÔ∏è. As we lift broad population-based #PhysicalDistancing measures like work closures, we need to ‚¨ÜÔ∏èintensity of other measures like #TestandTrace to maintain epidemic control.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 Modelled scenarios show the impact of different combinations of #publichealth measures like #PhysicalDistancing, detecting & isolating cases, and tracing & quarantine of contacts. #TestandTrace #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/6 Check out the June issue of the Canada Communicable Disease Report describing how PHAC‚Äôs epidemic modelling is used to inform decisions on #PublicHealth measures for control of #COVID19.   https://t.co/bKJjpgqRnt  https://t.co/2lVH5Uy2mK

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 Answering 2 simple Yes/No questions a week can help track COVID-19 in your community. Support #PublicHealth in your community by joining FluWatchers. The more participants in your area, the more accurate the data.  https://t.co/ZxyGqcpXXy #CitizenScience

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 Over 11,000 #FluWatchers reporting this week. Keeping it steady 2 weeks in a row with only 0.15% reporting symptoms of cough and fever. Thank you to all the #volunteer FluWatchers reporting each week. You are helping our understanding of #COVID19. #TogetherApart  https://t.co/VsfSaopYRC

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/7 That‚Äôs why we have to #KeepItUp w\ #PhysicalDistancing, #GoodHygiene , #CoughEtiquette & #TestandTrace other #publichealth measures, because THE FATE OF THE POSSIBILITIES IS UP TO US. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/7 Nevertheless, modelling projections provide a range of possibilities. They are not actual crystal balls because what happens in THE FUTURE DEPENDS ON WHAT WE DO. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/7 To avoid this worst-case scenario, modelling experts illustrated how proven effective #publichealth interventions like #PhysicalDistancing, #goodhygiene & #infectioncontrol could #FlattenTheCurve, to maintain health system capacity & ‚Üì deaths.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/7 For #COVID19, this type of model is what showed us that if we did ‚ÄúA. nothing‚Äù the epidemic would spike over a short period of time w\ maximum hospitalisations & critical cases overwhelming our healthcare system & ‚¨ÜÔ∏èdeath rates. (Image credit: Drew Harris @drewaharris)  https://t.co/oyqtcsLJFi

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/7 These models can predict numbers of cases but their strength is in guiding planning by illustrating which trajectory is best between e.g. an option A. ‚Äúdo nothing worst case scenario‚Äù vs. option ‚ÄúB‚Äù or ‚ÄúC‚Äù intervention scenarios. #COVID19  https://t.co/2jk9QCMIYT

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/7 Together with data on how #publichealth & intervention measures can impact spread. This way the model can show us how different options for intervention might change the epidemic trajectory. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/7 While transmission data models don‚Äôt use case-based surveillance data to predict, they do use data on known epidemiological parameters that influence how #COVID19 spreads, e.g. average # of contacts, duration of infectiousness etc.,

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 If I haven‚Äôt lost you yet, read the next thread on how the second type of model, transmission models, are used to answer BIG questions like comparing a worst case scenario vs. intervention options to modify a dire trajectory. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 Caution & caveats apply, but models show us that our #publichealth practices matter to prevent a worst case scenario [done] & we need to #KeepItUp #TogetherApart to maintain #COVID19 epidemic control to avoid a possible rebound wave.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 PHAC uses this modelling to track progress using the latest surveillance data. Even if predictions shift rapidly & only look days ahead, we can observe how the actions of Canadians #TogetherApart is working to control #COVID19 spread  https://t.co/6KpgyKfaj1  https://t.co/HAthB25NPQ

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 To correct for this, surveillance data models are limited to modest, short-term predictions (days) of the trajectory & are regularly updated & re-run as new case data come in, to account for changes & correct the predicted path. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 These models can be inaccurate if the context & circumstances DO change over time. Every change in context & our actions (#PhysicalDistancing, new disease introduction or cluster, etc.) makes the real outcome diverge from the forecast. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/6 Surveillance Data Models use actual data to plot how a disease behaves over a certain period of time, in a specific context & set of circumstances to PREDICT what could happen in the short term IF NO CHANGES in context/circumstances. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/10 It often seems easier & less discomforting to just stick with a new habit, but when a new habit is having a negative impact, whether on our #mentalhealth, physical or social wellbeing or otherwise, it‚Äôs time to make a change for the better.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/10 Adapting to change is hard. Once we‚Äôve made a change it can be hard to go back to previous healthy habits. Some have compared this with reverse culture shock. Whatever it is, the discomfort & inertia we feel is real. #COVID19 #Anxiety

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/10 Other habits during #COVID19, like increasing alcohol consumption & not being as physically active as before are clearly not so healthy and it‚Äôs important to put the effort in to replace these changes with healthier routines.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/10 Some habits that we‚Äôve developed during #COVID19, like more frequent #handwashing and spending more time with our families, can be good things that we‚Äôll want to carry on with going forward. #COVIDCoping

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/10 The reality is we have adapted staying at home into our daily routines over the weeks and months of the #COVID19 pandemic and it has now become our habit.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/3 Recommended for EVERYONE during #heatwave & #COVID19: drink lots of water, avoid strenuous activities & maintain #publichealth practices: #PhysicalDistancing, #Handwashing & #CoughEtiquette, while you seek heat relief & #HelpOthers.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/3 Non-medical masks or cloth face coverings are NOT for everyone! They should not be used on young children < age 2 or anyone who has trouble breathing, is unconscious, incapacitated or otherwise unable to remove it on their own.  More info:  https://t.co/a96yJ8KMkh

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/3 In high heat & humidity, wearing a mask can make breathing difficult. So, when outdoors, #PhysicalDistancing is best. Reserve non-medical mask for use indoors, for short periods of time when #PhysicalDistancing cannot be maintained.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/4 Managing summer heat is challenging, but during #COVID19 it is even more complex. Wherever you live, stay informed about your local weather forecasts and find out what your municipality is doing to help people beat the heat safely. #COVIDCoping

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/4 #HelpOthers by checking in on older members of your family & community to make sure they are ok‚Äîwhether they live in a long-term care home or on their own. Let‚Äôs ensure that those most vulnerable to extreme heat get some relief. #heatwave & #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/4 I am very concerned about seniors who have already faced devastating outcomes from #COVID19. Extreme heat can worsen pre-existing conditions & breathing difficulties, esp. as some #OlderAdults may not have access to air conditioning.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 #Heatwave in ON/QC: ‚ö†Ô∏èof health risks posed by extreme heat, esp. for older adults, infants & young children, people w\ chronic illnesses & people who work in the heat, are in low-income households or experiencing homelessness.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 In some cases, virtual appointments may be available. Speak with your health care provider to see what options are available for you and your family to safely have your health needs met. #COVID19 #COVIDCoping

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 Healthcare providers have implemented a range precautions to prevent the spread of #COVID19 & ensure patient safety, such as screening patients before appointments, staggering visit times to maintain #PhysicalDistancing

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 Likewise delayed or missed appointments for prevention visits, e.g. to maintain routine vaccinations for children and adults, increases the risk for infectious disease outbreaks and associated illnesses & deaths. #VaccinesWork #PublicHealth

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 Delays in seeking urgent care for life-threatening illness like heart attack & stroke can result in immediate ‚Üë in death rates. Delays in chronic disease management like #diabetes care can ‚Üë illness & death rates down the line.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 This includes keeping health visits for everything from prevention & #vaccines, to #MentalHealth & chronic disease management and not delaying for immediate attention for life-threatening health & mental health concerns. #COVIDCoping

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/6 As we consider the broader impacts of #COVID19 on the health of Canadians, I am reminding everyone that it is vital to maintain health visits for you and your family. #ChronicDiseases #Vaccines #MentalHealth

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/7 Despite limitations, @StatCan_eng‚Äôs planned monthly reports, w\ new weeks of data added as available, will provide important ongoing monitoring of excess mortality data as #COVID19 continues.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/7 @StatCan_eng cautions it does not currently have information on causes of death necessary to confirm that any excess mortality can be attributed to #COVID19. Comprehensive analysis of excess mortality await these data.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/7 ...and other natural and external causes of death. It is important to note that estimates of excess mortality are based on provisional counts, thus subject to change. Caveats & limitations of the data should be carefully considered.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/7 These provisional data include deaths from all causes, and any observed increases & decreases in deaths can be due to causes other than #COVID19, from cancer, heart disease & stroke to accidents, suicide, overdoses...

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/7 delayed health seeking for acute & chronic health conditions, etc. Examining excess deaths is an important way to understand the full impact of an extraordinary event like the #COVID19 pandemic against historic mortality rates.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/8 We will be living with #COVID19 for some time. If we make it a priority to look after the most vulnerable in our society, we can change the outcome of this pandemic and not live in its shadow. Together, we can do this. #ProtectTheVulnerable

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/8 That means providing better financial and other supports to essential workers in these settings, so that we stand a better chance of maintaining control of #COVID19. #PersonalSupportWorkers #HealthcareHeroes

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/8 Where there are weaknesses, whether structural, social or economic in nature, this virus will take advantage. We need to be willing to do what it takes to address these weaknesses in long term care & assisted living homes. #COVID19 #PersonalSupportWorkers

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/8 Canada‚Äôs older adults are our elders, they are the keepers of our history, culture and wisdom. Each loss is one too many but the scale and impact on our seniors as a whole is nothing short of a national tragedy. #COVID19 #COVIDLoss

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/8 A range of measures has been implemented in an effort to prevent introduction & spread of #COVID19 in long-term care homes. Yet, many areas of üá®üá¶ are still struggling to get ahead of the rapid & stealthy spread of this virus.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/8 But it is older adults who bear the brunt of #COVID19. Though an estimated 20% of COVID-19 cases in Canada are linked to long-term care homes, over 80% of all deaths are among seniors residing in these settings. #ProtecttheVulnerable

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/8 Prevention & control of #COVID19 in high-risk populations is crucial for controlling this & future pandemic waves. These outbreaks drive up the case fatality rate, accelerate spread, & continue to spillover into the community.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/8 Today my remarks focus on the disproportionate impacts and severe outcomes of #COVID19 on seniors. It‚Äôs hard to calculate the hardships endured and the grief that remains for those we‚Äôve lost. #OlderAdults

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 Sustainable changes, including appropriate supports for those who live, work & care for others in these settings. Big efforts = Best outcomes. Let‚Äôs get this right Canada. Let‚Äôs corner & conquer this virus! #COVID19 #ProtecttheVulnerable #PersonalSupportWorkers

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 12/12 üá®üá¶ continues to increase testing capacity, while focussing on testing the RIGHT PEOPLE (high-risk of exposure), at the RIGHTTIME (time in illness when viral load‚Üë), in the RIGHT PLACES (where #COVID19 is present). #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 11/12 This ensures that all individuals who are at higher risk of #COVID19 exposure will get tested, allowing us to institute comprehensive testing as soon as any case is detected in these high-risk settings. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 10/12 Currently, our laboratory testing strategy is evolving as the #COVID19 epidemic continues to slow. In many areas of Canada, testing is broadening to include people with a range of milder symptoms (casting wide). #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 9/12 At the same time, we have doubled the # of people being tested for #COVID19 weekly since early April (from >92,000 people tested/week in early April to >184,000 people tested/week in early May), as net is cast wide. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/12 üá®üá¶ has maintained %  positivity rates below 10% throughout the #COVID19 epidemic. Most encouragingly, our average weekly % positivity rate has  been steadily declining, from 9.8% in early April to about 4% in early May,  2020.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/12 The wider the net is cast, the lower the % positivity as we find the exposed people (positive tests) among the many more not exposed (negative tests) to narrow in on the burden of #COVID19 spread in the community. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/12 The @WHO testing benchmark for #COVID19 is to aim for a positivity rate of 10% or below, striking a balance between casting the net wide (sensitive surveillance), while targeting testing where the virus is likely to be spreading. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/12 How do we know we are testing enough? One relatively simple international benchmark is to monitor the % of #COVID19 tests that come back positive, where the lower the % positive (<10%) the better your surveillance is.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/12 A key aspect of an effective testing approach is to ensure it is aligned with & able to adapt to the current & changing #epidemiology of #COVID19 to inform clinical diagnosis & drive appropriate #publichealth action.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/12 Specifically, robust testing capacity is a vital component of our #TestandTrace approach to quickly detect and isolate cases, and trace and quarantine contacts in order to rapidly corner the virus & control #COVID19.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/12 To be clear, when we talked about üá®üá¶‚Äôs current lab capacity to do 60,000 tests a day, this was about building up our ability (equipment/supplies/people) to detect any surge in cases, as we relax #publichealth measures.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/12 There are lots of questions about our current level of lab testing (average 27,000 people tested per day in the last 7 days) versus our current lab capacity to test up to 60,000 people daily for #COVID19. This thread elaborates.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/2 Small sparks of #COVID19 transmission are not unexpected as we start to reopen workplaces. That‚Äôs why #PhysicalDistancing, #GoodHygiene, and #StayHomeIfSick must continue, to limit spread & stamp out little fires.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/2 #COVID19 key concerns in üá®üá¶: Though some small outbreaks have been reported in workplace settings in recent weeks, early detection when case numbers are low, allows for rapid #publichealth response to control spread. #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/5 Children and youth have also created virtual choirs, and used their #STEM skills to develop Apps and #COVID19 data trackers. Reinforcing positive energy helps to build resilience, not just for youth, but for all of us! #StrongerTogether

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

tweet: 3/5 Talking things out can help to process our thoughts and lift the weight of our emotions. When you start the conversation and share your own thoughts & feelings, it helps children & youth to open up and voice their own struggles. #StrongerTogether #GetReal

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/7 Talking things out can help you and also help others who may be finding it difficult to voice their own struggles. We may still be apart physically, but by talking about how you‚Äôre feeling you‚Äôll find you are not alone. #WeWillGetThroughThis #cavabienaller

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/7 So as we move forward into the uncertain days ahead, don‚Äôt be afraid to speak up and talk if you are struggling with the weight of what you‚Äôre feeling. #GetReal #ApartNotAlone #COVIDCoping

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/7 These mental health experts remind us that for the sake of our mental wellness we shouldn‚Äôt bury or hide our emotions. Let‚Äôs not forget that we‚Äôre on this road together and there is help. #GetReal #COVIDCoping #StrongerTogether

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/7 In recognition of the challenges and uncertainties we are all facing, @CMHA_NTL is leading the way on #MentalHealthWeek by encouraging us to #GetReal with our feelings.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/7 People have been struggling with concerns of all manner & scope during these long weeks of #COVID19. This #MentalHealthWeek‚Äôs focus on social connection reminds us it is a very important time to stay connected. #ApartNotAlone  https://t.co/tY5dcLZIxV

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/7 This year‚Äôs #MentalHealthWeek continues through to Sunday, May 10th, with #MentalHealth taking on a special meaning in light of the additional stress and uncertainty we are all experiencing due to #COVID19.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/7 So although not all #vaccines are needle-free, it helps to know that even if there is a little sting, soon your body will be ready to fight off a new bad bug & you‚Äôll be an immunity hero, protecting others around you too! #CommunityImmunity

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/7 It can also help if you bring a favourite toy or game to take your mind away from being scared ‚Äì and It‚Äôs okay to tell the nurse or doctor that you‚Äôre scared & need a moment or you can ask the adult with you to hold your hand. #VaccinesWork

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/7 Scientists are also working to develop other safe & effective no needle options. For now, though most #vaccines are by needle, there are ways to prevent pain, like dabbing on a liquid to numb your skin so you won‚Äôt feel the sting!

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/7 So far, very few #vaccines are available without needles. There is one kind of #flu vaccine that can be squirted into the nose as mist. It‚Äôs not always available but scientists are working hard to make more of this type of #flu vaccine.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/7 In the meantime, to answer the question on the minds of kids everywhere - yes, we do have some needle-free solutions now as well as other ways to reduce the pain and make needles less scary. #VaccinesWork

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 There is simply nothing like a splash of water, a bit of soap & a 20 second scrub to clean hands & beat back the bad bugs. Make sure to clean back & front of hands, between fingers, thumbs & fingertips & repeat often, it‚Äôs a life saver! #HandHygiene

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 @ToyinSaraki provides a bit of history on this lifesaving practice of #handhygiene ‚ÄúIt is an apt coincidence that Int'l Day of the Midwife coincides with Clean Hands Day today‚Äù see: #cleanhandsday #IDM2020 #ApplaudwithWASH #SupportNursesAndMidwives    https://t.co/K7v0ffdfsM

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 Personal hygiene, esp. #handhygiene, is an important component of human well-being that is practised the world over. In fact, #handwashing can mean the difference between life & death. #cleanhandsday

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 It‚Äôs World #handhygiene day, an annual event in conjunction w\ @WHO‚Äôs global campaign for ‚ÄúSAVE LIVES: Clean Your Hands‚Äù that highlights how good hand hygiene is a basic but lifesaving #publichealth practice.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 ‚Ä¶and even droplet respiratory infections like #COVID19, would you pick a favourite tune & sing to yourself while you #WashYourHands for 20 seconds? ‚Äì cause that‚Äôs all it takes!    https://t.co/JRrHZLdtpT

tweet: 1/6 If I was to tell you that there was one super low cost solution that could significantly reduce everybody‚Äôs likelihood of catching a whole range of diseases from stomach bugs to antibiotic resistant infections‚Ä¶
