name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 Hand sanitizers work in the same way, but in order to be effective they need to have at least 60% alcohol content and you need to rub all over till dry. Makes sense to #WashYourHands! #Science

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6  https://t.co/oy9LxLy7Fp can customise your favourite song into a 20 second handwashing poster so you can sing along to follow all the steps for good #handwashing!

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 For best results, 1st rinse with a bit of water, then rub or dispense soap & rub all over hands for 20 seconds ‚Äì back of hands, front of hands, between fingers, finger tips & don‚Äôt forget your thumbs & nails. Then rinse and dry your hands well.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 What you do need, is the right amount of time and care to rub the soap all over every part of your hands ‚Äì that‚Äôs why you should #WashYourHands for at least 20 seconds.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 This causes the virus to dissolve in water, disintegrating so it flushes down the drain.  Any kind of soap will do! You don‚Äôt need antibacterial or other specialsoaps.  #SaveLivesCleanYourHands

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/6 Did you know that #handwashing with soap & water destroys the novel #coronavirus that causes #COVID19? Soap molecules are attracted to fat so they get into the virus‚Äô shell (made of fat & protein), then break it apart.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/4 #COVID19 key concerns in üá®üá¶: overall growth continues to slow, w\ case counts now doubling only every 16 days (vs. 3-5 day doubling earlier), but outbreaks in high-risk populations continue to drive regional epidemics.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 11/11 Our collective efforts have already slowed the growth of #COVID19, bent the curve and enabled our health system to cope throughout. These are no small feats and they tell us #WeWillGetThroughThis #CavaBienAller! #KeepItUp #L√¢chePasLaPatate

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 10/11 Measures will need to remain flexible & adaptable to alerts and signals. Although we will be living with #COVID19 for the foreseeable future, #StrongerTogether we can keep this virus at bay by remaining vigilant.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 9/11 Local/Provincial & Territorial level reopening plans are key to managing this next phase of #COVID19. Based on public health criteria, effective #publichealth measures are being balanced against potential negative consequences.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/11 As well, other critical #publichealth capacity must be in place & maintained across Canada in order to ensure adequate testing to detect alerts and respond quickly to any new #COVID19 disease activity.  #TestandTrace

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/11 All areas of üá®üá¶ know that prevention practices are a vital part of reopening plans for workplaces, schools & businesses, like keeping 2m ‚Üî #PhysicalDistancing, when out or in the workplace & #handwashing, always. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/11 Some areas of üá®üá¶ are seeing few or no recent #COVID19 cases & have started gradual social & economic reopening plans, while maintaining key public health practices, like #PhysicalDistancing & limited social gathering.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/11 The epidemiological picture of #COVID19 in üá®üá¶, w\ slowed growth & bending of the epidemic curve is actually a composite of very different regional outbreaks/drivers of spread, so it depends on where you are.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/11 With the current promising signs of #COVID19 slowed growth, we are increasingly hearing of reopening plans but this won‚Äôt happen at the same time or in the same way everywhere across the country.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/11 If we maintain measures that keep the #COVID19 growth rate down and prevent outbreaks and potential rebound of spread, we stand the best chance of remaining on this favourable trajectory. #KeepItUp #PlankTheCurve

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/11 The #COVID19 forecast for üá®üá¶ is looking better, though we are not entirely out of the woods yet. We must remain mindful that our projections are only as reliable as our actions. #PlankTheCurve #PhysicalDistancing #WashYourHands

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 10/10 When to relax/adjust #publichealth measures will vary based on local context & #COVID19 #epidemiology Relaxing controls too quickly could squander our collective efforts to date & put us at risk of future epidemic waves.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 9/10 Until üá®üá¶ has widespread high-level population immunity to the virus or an effective vaccine available, some type & degree of #publichealth measures will be needed to prevent & control sparking & fueling of future #COVID19 waves.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/10 To stay with the best-case scenario: continue tried & true #publichealth measures, incl. #PhysicalDistancing, good #handwashing + continue ‚Üë #testandtrace to detect/isolate #COVID19 cases & trace/quarantine contacts. #KeepItUp #L√¢chePasLaPatate!

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/10 We are observing slowed epidemic growth and a flattening of the curve across most jurisdictions in Canada.  At this time, the number of cases is doubling at a rate of every 16 days.  Way to go Canada!

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/10 #Publichealth & collective efforts of Canadians have helped get us very near that goal. Now, on average, each person infects just over 1 other person, ‚Üì from spread to over 2 other people, early in the #COVID19 epidemic! #KeepItUp #TeamCanada

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/10 The goal of #publichealth action is to #SlowtheSpread of #COVID19 so, on average, each infected person is only able to infect LESS THAN 1 other person.  This causes the epidemic runs out of fuel.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/10 Dynamic models show what COULD happen under different scenarios with ‚Üë versus ‚Üì epidemic control, which helps us plan & drive #publichealth measures toward a best outcome & away from a worst-case scenario. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/10 Today‚Äôs #GOC forecast model gives a short-term prediction out to May 5th of between 53,000-67,000 #COVID19 cases & 3,300-3,900 deaths, but ‚Üë cases in high-risk individuals can ‚Üë case fatality rate, leading to underprediction.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/10 Today I presented an update on #GOC modelling that includes two types of approaches: 1. forecasting for short-term predictions & 2. dynamic modelling for hypothetical ‚Äúif, then‚Äù planning scenarios. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/6 Epidemiological data confirm that #OlderAdults & those with pre-existing health condition(s) are at increased risk for severe illness. However, no one is immune to severe outcomes of #COVID19.

tweet: 5/6 Data currently available on other severe outcomes of #COVID19 cases in üá®üá¶ show that up to 17% of cases have required hospitalization & almost 5% have required admission to ICU for treatment of critical illness.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

tweet: 6/6 To prevent a resurgence of #COVID19 epidemic growth we must prevent similar outbreaks from occurring in shelters & other crowded (or congregate) living settings. We‚Äôve got to build up all protections & address all vulnerabilities. #PhysicalDistancing

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 If we are to #CrushtheCurve of #COVID19, we must stamp out all of the burning embers of this disease that continue to fuel outbreaks and can lead to new chains of transmission. #PhysicalDistancing #PublicHealth

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/6 The risk factors in these types of settings aren‚Äôt new. The fact is that enclosed spaces with large populations sharing common areas that can‚Äôt maintain optimal #PhysicalDistancing are at risk for outbreaks. #publichealth #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 We‚Äôve got to act quickly to address weak points before the virus is introduced to other vulnerable settings.  We can‚Äôt let the virus jump ahead of us again. #ProtecttheVulnerable #PlanktheCurve #CrushtheCurve

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/7 It is vitally important to protect high-risk settings from #COVID19. Vulnerabilities in these settings are a long-standing problem but it is now incumbent upon us to solve these issues by addressing all weak points in the system.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/7 ‚Üë CFR is one reason that models can ‚Äùunder-predict‚Äù the #/range of deaths, even for short-term forecasting. Other factors, like outbreaks occurring among higher risk/vulnerable populations also affect accuracy of the prediction. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/7 But increasing CFR is only a temporary phenomenon ‚Äì as epidemic growth slows near the end, the CFR will stabilize. The final CFR will still be higher than the rate that was calculated during the early part of the epidemic. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/7 Then just as things seem to be getting better with the epidemic growth rate slowing down, deaths begin to accumulate at a faster pace and the calculated case fatality rate (CFR) likewise increases. #COVID19 #ProtecttheVulnerable #OlderAdults

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/7 This creates a bit of a paradox: when early in an epidemic there is a rapid #ExponentialGrowth of new cases but a slower accumulation of deaths, so the calculated case fatality rate (CFR) is relatively low. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 9/9 This is a critical stage for #COVID19 in üá®üá¶. We can‚Äôt afford to relax proven #PublicHealth measures that protect YOU: #PhysicalDistancing #WashYourHands #CoughEtiquette & regularly disinfect high-touch surfaces. #PlanktheCurve

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/9 ‚ö†Ô∏èfacial coverings are NOT appropriate for everyone. They could be a suffocation risk for babies & children under the 2 yrs; anyone w\ difficulty breathing or others unable to remove their mask by themselves. #ProtecttheVulnerable #LayerUpCOVID

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/9 Even if you have no symptoms‚ÄïNON-MEDICAL/facial coverings masks need to be used IN ADDITION TO and NOT _in place of_ proven #publichealth practices like: #PhysicalDistancing, #WashYourHands, #CoughEtiquette. #LayerUpCOVID #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/9 When #PhysicalDistancing is difficult to do e.g. while on public transit/ in a grocery store, a NON-MEDICAL mask/facial covering can help to: ‚Üì spread of infected respiratory droplets to others & ‚Üì contamination of surfaces. #COVID19 #LayerUpCOVID

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/9 Wearing a NON-MEDICAL mask in public settings has not been proven to add any protection TO the person wearing it, but it can be an additional way to prevent spread FROM an infected person to others. #ProtectDontInfect #COVID19 #LayerUpCOVID

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/9 ! MEDICAL masks MUST be conserved for healthcare workers & others in direct care of #COVID19 patients. Masks for public use mean only NON-MEDICAL masks & facial coverings (homemade cloth mask, bandana, common dust mask) #LayerUpCOVID

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/9 üá®üá¶‚Äôs Special Advisory Committee on #COVID19 reached consensus on NON-MEDICAL masks/FACIAL COVERINGS‚Äô use in public as an added layer of protection to help YOU PROTECT OTHERS by reducing spread of droplets, even before you have symptoms. #LayerUpCOVID  https://t.co/hsS5t3xQio

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/9 As #COVID19 research emerges, #Publichealth experts & researchers across üá®üá¶ critically evaluate the strength of new evidence before recommending safe ways to change practices. Prevention MUST be layered. #LayerUpCOVID

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/9 To stay healthy & prevent spread of #COVID19 we MUST use multiple prevention measures TOGETHER like keeping 2 metres away from others, frequent #handwashing, covering coughs‚Ä¶ ‚Äì we need layers of protection. #Olderadults #LayerUpCOVID

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/3 There is also evidence that some infected people who never develop symptoms are also able to transmit the virus. This is called asymptomatic transmission. #COVID19 #LayerUpCOVID #PlanktheCurve

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/3 This means that the virus causing #COVID19 can be spread from an infected person in the period _just before_ their symptoms appear. Evidence suggests that this is happening more often than previously thought. #PlanktheCurve

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1/3 Global science on #COVID19 is emerging at a fast pace. Recent studies from countries that have analysed transmission patterns for large numbers of cases now demonstrate pre-symptomatic virus spread is occurring.  #PlanktheCurve

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/6 We know #coughetiquette reduces spread of infectious respiratory droplets TO OTHERS ‚Äì IF coughs covered & no gaps in elbow/sleeve, mask/other covering (‚¨ÖÔ∏ègap?) AND IF covering cleaned/discarded properly when contaminated (‚¨ÖÔ∏ègaps). #LayerUpCOVID #ProtectDontInfect

tweet: 4/6 We know that #HandWashing ‚Äì with soap & water for at least 20 seconds ‚Äì works, well ‚Äì IF done frequently and after every possible hand contamination (‚¨ÖÔ∏ègap?) AND IF - you don‚Äôt miss a spot (‚¨ÖÔ∏ègap?) #COVID19 #PlanktheCurve #LayerUpCOVID

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/6 We know that #SocialDistancing - keeping 2-metres apart from others ‚Äì works, well ‚ÄìIF practiced consistently & never relaxed around others (‚¨ÖÔ∏ègap?) & we assume anyone ‚Üî could be potentially infected (‚¨ÖÔ∏ègap?) #COVID19 #StayHomeSaveLives #LayerUpCOVID

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/6 Where there is a gap or fail in one layer of protection, the layer above or below aims to cover that gap and maintain our protection. Canada knows how to layer for ‚òÄÔ∏è‚ùÑÔ∏è‚òîÔ∏è ‚Äì here‚Äôs how to layer up for #COVID19. #PlanktheCurve #LayerUpCOVID

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 8/8 When & by how much we #PlanktheCurve for üá®üá¶ is up to Every. Single. One. of. Us. The efforts of all Canadians are needed at this critical time ‚Äì To get this done we need an all out collective effort. #COVID19 #DoYourPart #TeamCanada

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/8 In addition to stopping new infections, characteristics of #COVID19, like incubation time (time between exposure & onset of symptoms) & illness duration, mean it can take several weeks before you can see a real effect on the epi curve.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/8 As the latest cases are added to the epi curve, like coins into a coin sorter, a more clear & accurate trend emerges. Early on, it may look like cases have peaked & are going down but this is due to missing data in the ‚Äúgrey zone‚Äù.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/8 Each step from illness onset to reporting adds to the time lag: a person gets sick ‚û°Ô∏è seeks healthcare ‚û°Ô∏è gets tested ‚û°Ô∏è gets diagnosed & investigated by #PublicHealth ‚û°Ô∏è case info gets reported ‚û°Ô∏è #COVID19 case added to the epi curve.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/8 The key issue is the time lag between when a case first has symptoms (the date against which cases are plotted on the curve) and when PHAC receives a case report (real-time date). For #COVID19 this time lag is about 1 to 2 weeks.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/8 While the outbreak is ongoing & still evolving, patterns can be a bit tricky to interpret. This is because we are only seeing a subset of all cases, with the most recent cases not yet reported. #COVID19 #FlattentheCurve

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/8 An epidemic curve (epi curve) is a great way to visualise the trend of an outbreak & see the pattern of illnesses occurring over time. But the patterns are most clear in hindsight, once all the case data has been reported & plotted.  https://t.co/4Jr38cuFqX  https://t.co/QqRxCbFpEX

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 7/7 ‚ö†Ô∏è Non-medical masks alone will not prevent #COVID19 spread. You must consistently and strictly adhere to #goodhygiene & #publichealth measures, including frequent #handwashing and #PhysicalDistancing (2 metres). #WashYourHands to be protected.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 6/7 ‚ö†Ô∏è Remember that you can also become infected if the virus enters the mucus membranes of your eyes. Do NOT touch or rub your eyes, especially after touching your face mask that could be contaminated with the virus. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 5/7 ‚ö†Ô∏è Know that masks can become contaminated on the outside, or when touched by your hands. Avoid touching your face mask while using it, wash & disinfect if fabric or discard & replace it with a new mask as soon as it gets damp. #COVID19

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 4/7 ‚ö†Ô∏è In order to avoid getting infected with or spreading #COVID19, when you wear a face mask: it should be well-fitted (no gaps) & you must practice #goodhygiene before, during & after wearing it. #WashYourHands

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3/7 NON-MEDICAL MASKS (e.g. homemade face masks) may stop you from touching your nose and mouth. A non-medical mask could help maintain #coughetiquette by covering your cough if you are ill or have early symptoms of #COVID19. BUT BEWARE:

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2/7 MEDICAL MASKS for #healthcare workers in patient care settings is PRIORITY #1 ‚Äì we MUST conserve these masks for use by & ONLY by #healthcare workers or others providing direct care to #COVID19 patients.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: Read the full statement for more tips on how to reduce the potential negative health impacts of cannabis use:  https://t.co/4dnsO68rsU

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 3Ô∏è‚É£ Keep it out of reach! Edible cannabis may look like regular food. To keep children & pets safe, label and store cannabis securely by keeping it out of reach and contained in original or clearly labelled, child resistant packaging.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 2Ô∏è‚É£ The strength is in the label! Read the label carefully to understand product strength. Up to 10mg of THC can be contained in a single package of edible cannabis! ‚Äì a large amount for a first-time or infrequent consumer of cannabis.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Start low, go slow - start with small amounts of 2.5 mg of THC or less of #edibles; then wait to feel the effects before taking more ‚Äì up to 2 hours to feel 1st effects of #edibles, & up to 4 hours to feel the full effects.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: Read the latest advice from Canada's Chief Medical Officers of Health on reducing the risks of edible cannabis consumption.  https://t.co/4dnsO6q2ks

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: The only way to completely avoid the risks associated with cannabis use is to not use it, but if you consume edibles be aware of the ways to minimize the health risks.

name: Dr. Theresa Tam
tweet: New Cannabis products are becoming legally available across üá®üá¶. Read the latest statement of the Council of Chief Medical Officers of Health to learn how to reduce the health risks associated with using #cannabis extracts, #edibles and topical products.  https://t.co/NHuRcDCQ8d
